key_points: DarkSide ransomware group used a "ransomware-as-a-service" model, partnering with affiliates to launch attacks.
The group, since its emergence last August, employed "double extortion" tactics, stealing sensitive data before encrypting files.
DarkSide targeted organizations based on careful financial analysis or information from corporate emails.
They used advanced techniques like "zero-day exploits" to infiltrate and swiftly move within target networks.
They also investigated victims' cyber insurance policies to tailor ransom demands.
Christopher Ballod from Kroll noted DarkSide's quick attack window and demands on the high end, typically $5 million+.
DarkSide threatened to share stolen information with short-sellers if publicly traded companies refused to pay ransom.
DarkSide listed its victims on the dark web, showcasing the confidential data stolen.
Post shutdown, affiliates complained on a forum that DarkSide had not paid them their share of ransoms.
Seven of Tantleff's clients paid ransoms ranging from $1.25 million to $6 million after negotiations from higher initial demands.
